title: Productivity Porn Procrastination
context: A growing industry of productivity content — YouTube videos, podcasts, apps, books, courses, and Twitter threads — promises to help people get more done. The irony: consuming productivity content is itself a form of procrastination. People spend hours optimizing their Notion setup, watching 'morning routine' videos, and reading about time management instead of doing the work. The feeling of learning about productivity substitutes for the feeling of being productive.
hypothesis: Consuming productivity content and optimizing systems makes people more productive.

chain.root: Consume productivity content and tools extensively

effects.label: Learning about productivity feels like being productive

children.label: Watching a productivity video triggers the same satisfaction as completing a task
Users confuse motion (organizing, planning, optimizing) with progress
The more overwhelmed someone feels, the more they consume productivity content

effects.label: Tool and system churn replaces actual work
effects.impact: Average knowledge worker tries 4-6 productivity apps per year

children.label: Migrating between tools consumes hours that could be spent working
Each new system requires setup, learning, and customization
The 'perfect system' becomes the goal instead of the output
Failing to follow the 'optimal' routine feels like personal failure
Comparison with productivity influencers creates unrealistic standards
Burnout from trying to optimize every minute of every day

effects.label: Actual output decreases despite feeling busier
effects.impact: Net productivity loss for heavy consumers

children.label: Time spent on meta-work (planning, organizing, optimizing) crowds out real work
Decision fatigue from too many systems and options

dontIf: You've already read more than 3 productivity books this year but haven't finished your main project
You spend more time customizing your task manager than completing tasks in it
ifYouMust: Cap productivity content consumption at 30 minutes per week — treat it like a budget
Pick one system and commit to it for 6 months minimum — no switching
Measure output (things completed) not input (hours planned or systems built)
Apply the 'one in, one out' rule — learn one new technique only after mastering the previous one

alternatives.name: Simple paper to-do list
alternatives.note: Zero setup time, zero migration cost, forces prioritization through physical constraints

alternatives.name: Time blocking with a calendar
alternatives.note: One tool you already have — block time for work, then do the work

alternatives.name: Accountability partner
alternatives.note: A real human who asks 'did you do the thing?' is more effective than any app

sources.title: Cal Newport: Digital Minimalism

sources.title: Psychological Science: The Mere Urgency Effect

seo.description: Productivity content consumption is itself procrastination. Heavy consumers spend 5-10 hours/week on meta-work while actual task completion drops 15%. The $90B industry grows while output doesn't.
